title: ASL 10.8 — Community Advocacy & Leadership
objectives: Use ASL to discuss advocacy, leadership, and civic roles
Incorporate persuasive signing techniques for community issues
Demonstrate ability to present a short advocacy statement in ASL

vocab.def: Sign HELP with strong directional emphasis toward group.
C-handshape circles outward representing group togetherness.
R-hands move downward like laying claim.
Two S-hands rotate around each other.

sections.heading: Advocacy in the Deaf Community
sections.body: Students learn how ASL has been used historically for advocacy, from Deaf President Now (1988) to current policy discussions.

sections.heading: Persuasive Signing
sections.body: Practice persuasive language structures: TIME + TOPIC + STRONG ASSERTION. Emphasize non-manual markers like intensity in eyebrows and head tilt.

sections.heading: Role-Play: Community Meeting
sections.body: Students role-play as community members addressing an issue (e.g., accessibility in schools). Each presents a short statement in ASL.

items.q: Which event is a major historical Deaf advocacy moment?
Gloss a persuasive ASL phrase: 'We need equal access in schools now.'

items.prompt: How can you use ASL to lead or advocate in your own community?

reflectionPrompt: Record a 1-minute advocacy statement in ASL about an issue important to you (e.g., accessibility, inclusion, education).
summary: Students can now use ASL to discuss leadership, community, and advocacy, applying persuasive techniques and cultural context.

games.title: Advocacy Match
outcomes: Match advocacy scenarios with correct ASL gloss
